Thus for instance the product <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^2 \times {\Bbb R}" class="latex"> of the shrinking round 2-sphere and the Euclidean line is a <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solution, which we refer to as the <em>shrinking round 3-cylinder</em> <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^2 \times {\Bbb R}" class="latex">. <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdiamond&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdiamond&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdiamond&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\diamond" class="latex"></p>
<p><strong>Example 2.</strong> In one dimension, there are no <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions, as every manifold is flat; in particular, the 1-sphere (i.e. a circle) is <em>not</em> a <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solution (it is flat and also collapsed at large scales).  In two dimensions, the shrinking round 2-sphere <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^2" class="latex"> is <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solution, as discussed above.  We can quotient this by the obvious <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+Z%7D%2F2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+Z%7D%2F2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+Z%7D%2F2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="{\Bbb Z}/2" class="latex"> action to also get a shrinking round projective plane <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\Bbb{RP}^2" class="latex"> as a <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solution.  But we shall show in later lectures that if we restrict attention to oriented manifolds, then the shrinking round 2-sphere is the only 2-dimensional <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions; this result is due to Hamilton, see e.g. Chapter 5 of <a class="snap_noshots" href="http://www.ams.org/mathscinet-getitem?mr=2061425">Chow-Knopf</a>. For instance, the 2-cylinder <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E1+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E1+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E1+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^1 \times {\Bbb R}" class="latex"> is not a <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solution (it is both flat and collapsed at large scales). The cigar soliton (Example 3 from <a href="https://terrytao.wordpress.com/2008/04/24/285a-lecture-8-ricci-flow-as-a-gradient-flow-log-sobolev-inequalities-and-perelman-entropy/">Lecture 8</a>) also fails to be a <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solution due to it being collapsed at large scales.  <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdiamond&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdiamond&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdiamond&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\diamond" class="latex"><strong><br>
</strong></p>
<p><strong>Example 3.</strong> In three dimensions, we begin to get significantly more variety amongst <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions.  We have the round shrinking 3-sphere <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^3" class="latex">, but also all the quotients <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3%2F%5CGamma&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3%2F%5CGamma&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3%2F%5CGamma&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^3/\Gamma" class="latex"> of such round spheres by free finite group actions (including the projective space <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+RP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+RP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+RP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="{\Bbb RP}^3" class="latex">, but with many other examples.  We refer to these examples as <em>round shrinking 3-spherical space forms</em>.  We have also seen the shrinking round cylinder <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^2 \times {\Bbb R}" class="latex">; there are also finite quotients of this example such as shrinking round projective cylinder <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\Bbb{RP}^2 \times {\Bbb R}" class="latex">, or the quotient of the cylinder by the orientation-preserving free involution <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Comega%2Cz%29+%5Cmapsto+%28-%5Comega%2C-z%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Comega%2Cz%29+%5Cmapsto+%28-%5Comega%2C-z%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Comega%2Cz%29+%5Cmapsto+%28-%5Comega%2C-z%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="(\omega,z) \mapsto (-\omega,-z)" class="latex">.  We refer to these examples as the <em>unoriented and oriented quotients of the shrinking round 3-cylinder</em> respectively. The oriented quotient can be viewed as a half-cylinder <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%5B1%2C%2B%5Cinfty%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%5B1%2C%2B%5Cinfty%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%5B1%2C%2B%5Cinfty%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^2 \times [1,+\infty)" class="latex"> capped off with a punctured <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\Bbb{RP}^3" class="latex"> (and the whole manifold is in fact homeomorphic to a punctured <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\Bbb{RP}^3" class="latex">).   <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdiamond&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdiamond&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdiamond&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\diamond" class="latex"></p>
<p><strong>Example 4. </strong>One can also imagine perturbations of the shrinking solutions mentioned above.  For instance, one could imagine non-round versions of the shrinking <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^2" class="latex"> or shrinking <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+RP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+RP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+RP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="{\Bbb RP}^3" class="latex"> example, in which the manifold has sectional curvature which is still positive but not constant.  We shall informally refer to such solutions as <em>C-components</em> (we will define this term formally later, and explain the role of the parameter C).  Similarly one could imagine variants of the oriented quotient of the shrinking round cylinder, which are approximately round half-cylinders <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%5B1%2C%2B%5Cinfty%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%5B1%2C%2B%5Cinfty%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%5B1%2C%2B%5Cinfty%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^2 \times [1,+\infty)" class="latex"> capped off with what is topologically either a punctured <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\Bbb{RP}^3" class="latex"> or punctured <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^3" class="latex"> (i.e. with something homeomorphic to a ball); a 3-dimensional variant of a cigar soliton would fall into this category (such solitons have been constructed <a class="snap_noshots" href="http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0407453">by Bryant</a> and <a class="snap_noshots" href="http://www.ams.org/mathscinet-getitem?mr=1417944">by Cao</a>).  We informally refer to such solutions as <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="C" class="latex">-capped strong <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\varepsilon" class="latex">-tubes (we will define this term precisely later).  One can also consider <em>doubly <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="C" class="latex">-capped strong <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\varepsilon" class="latex">-tubes</em>, in which an approximately round finite cylinder <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%5B-T%2CT%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%5B-T%2CT%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%5B-T%2CT%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^2 \times [-T,T]" class="latex"> is capped off at both ends by either a punctured <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\Bbb{RP}^3" class="latex"> or punctured <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^3" class="latex">; such manifolds then become homeomorphic to either <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^3" class="latex"> or <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+RP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+RP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+RP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="{\Bbb RP}^3" class="latex">.  (Note we need to cap off any ends that show up in order to keep the manifold M complete.)  <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdiamond&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdiamond&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdiamond&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\diamond" class="latex"></p>
<p>An important theorem of Perelman shows that these examples of <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions are in fact the only ones:</p>
<blockquote><p><strong>Theorem 1.</strong> (Perelman classification theorem, imprecise version)  Every 3-dimensional <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solution takes on one of the following forms at time zero (after isometry and rescaling, if necessary):</p>
<ol>
<li>A shrinking round 3-sphere <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^3" class="latex"> (or shrinking round spherical space form <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3%2F%5CGamma&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3%2F%5CGamma&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3%2F%5CGamma&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^3/\Gamma" class="latex">);</li>
<li>A shrinking round 3-cylinder <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^2 \times {\Bbb R}" class="latex">, the quotient <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\Bbb{RP}^2 \times {\Bbb R}" class="latex">, or one of its quotients (either oriented or unoriented);</li>
<li>A C-component;</li>
<li>A C-capped strong <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\varepsilon" class="latex">-tube;</li>
<li>A doubly C-capped strong <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\varepsilon" class="latex">-tube.</li>
</ol>
</blockquote>
<p>We will make this theorem more precise in later lectures (or if you are impatient, you can read Chapter 9 of <a class="snap_noshots" href="http://www.ams.org/mathscinet-getitem?mr=2334563">Morgan-Tian</a>).</p>
<p><strong>Remark 3.</strong> At very large scales, Theorem 1 implies that an ancient solution at time zero either looks 0-dimensional (because the manifold was compact, as in the case of a sphere, spherical space form, C-component, or doubly C-capped strong <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\varepsilon" class="latex">-tube) or 1-dimensional, resembling a line (in the case of the cylinder) or half-line (for C-capped strong <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\varepsilon" class="latex">-tube). Oversimplifying somewhat, this 0- or 1-dimensionality of the three-dimensional <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions is the main reason why surgery is even possible; if Ricci flow singularities could look 2-dimensional (such as <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E1+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E1+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E1+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^1 \times {\Bbb R}^2" class="latex">, or as the product of the cigar soliton and a line) or 3-dimensional (as in <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+R%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+R%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+R%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="{\Bbb R}^3" class="latex">) then it is not clear at all how to define a surgery procedure to excise the singularity.  The point is that all the potential candidates for singularity that look 2-dimensional or 3-dimensional at large scales (after rescaling) are either flat or collapsed (or do not have bounded nonnegative curvature), and so are not <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions.  The unoriented quotiented cylinder <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\Bbb{RP}^2 \times {\Bbb R}" class="latex"> also causes difficulties with surgery (despite being only one-dimensional at large scales), because it is hard to cap off such a cylinder in a manner which is well-behaved with respect to Ricci flow; however if we assume that the original manifold M contains no embedded copy of <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2+%5Ctimes+%7B%5CBbb+R%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\Bbb{RP}^2 \times {\Bbb R}" class="latex"> (which is for instance the case if the manifold is oriented, and in particular if it is simply connected) then this case does not occur. <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdiamond&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdiamond&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdiamond&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\diamond" class="latex"></p>
<p><strong>Remark 4.</strong> In four and higher dimensions, things look much worse; consider for instance the product of a shrinking round <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^2" class="latex"> with the trivial plane <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+R%7D%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+R%7D%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+R%7D%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="{\Bbb R}^2" class="latex">.  This is a <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solution but has a two-dimensional large-scale structure, and so there is no obvious way to remove singularities of this shape by surgery.  It may be that in order to have analogues of Perelman’s theory in higher dimensions one has to make much stronger topological or geometric assumptions on the manifold.  Note however that four-dimensional Ricci flows with surgery were already considered <a class="snap_noshots" href="http://www.ams.org/mathscinet-getitem?mr=862046">by Hamilton</a> (with a rather different definition of surgery, however).</p>
<p>The classification theorem lets one understand the geometry of neighbourhoods of any given point in a <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solution.  Let us make the following imprecise definitions (which, again, will be made precise in later lectures):</p>
<blockquote><p><strong>Definition 2. </strong> (Canonical neighbourhoods, informal version) Let (M,g) be a complete connected 3-manifold, let x be a point in M, and let U be an open neighbourhood of x.  We normalise the scalar curvature at x to be 1.</p>
<ol>
<li>We say that U is an <em><img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\varepsilon" class="latex">-neck</em> if it is close (in a smooth topology) to a round cylinder <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%28-R%2CR%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%28-R%2CR%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E2+%5Ctimes+%28-R%2CR%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^2 \times (-R,R)" class="latex">, with x well in the middle of of this cylinder;</li>
<li>We say that U is a <em>C-component</em> if U is diffeomorphic to <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^3" class="latex"> or <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\Bbb{RP}^3" class="latex"> (in particular, it must be all of M) with sectional curvatures bounded above and below by positive constants, and with diameter comparable to 1.</li>
<li>We say that U is <em><img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\varepsilon" class="latex">-round</em> if it is close (in a smooth topology) to a round sphere <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^3" class="latex"> or spherical space form <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3%2F%5CGamma&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3%2F%5CGamma&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E3%2F%5CGamma&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^3/\Gamma" class="latex"> (i.e. it is close to a constant curvature manifold).</li>
<li>We say that U is a <em><img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28C%2C%5Cvarepsilon%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28C%2C%5Cvarepsilon%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28C%2C%5Cvarepsilon%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="(C,\varepsilon)" class="latex">-cap</em> if it consists of an <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\varepsilon" class="latex">-neck together with a cap at one end, where the cap is homeomorphic to either an open 3-ball or a punctured <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+RP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+RP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%5CBbb+RP%7D%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="{\Bbb RP}^3" class="latex"> and obeys similar bounds as a C-component, and that x is contained inside the cap.  (For technical reasons one also needs some derivative bounds on curvature, but we omit them here.)</li>
<li>We say that U is a <em>canonical neighbourhood</em> of x if it is one of the above four types.</li>
</ol>
<p>When the scalar curvature is some other positive number than 1, we can generalise the above definition by rescaling the metric to have curvature 1.</p></blockquote>
<p>Using Theorem 1 (and defining all terms precisely), one can easily show the following important statement:</p>
<blockquote><p><strong>Corollary 1</strong> (Canonical neighbourhood theorem for <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solitons, informal version)  Every point in a 3-dimensional <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solution that does not contain an embedded copy of <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\Bbb{RP}^2" class="latex"> with trivial normal bundle is contained in a canonical neighbourhood.</p></blockquote>
<p>The next few lectures will be devoted to establishing precise versions of Theorem 1, Definition 2, and Corollary 1.</p>
<p style="text-align:center;">— High curvature regions of Ricci flows —</p>
<p>Corollary 1 is an assertion about <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions only, but it implies an important property about more general Ricci flows:</p>
<blockquote><p><strong>Theorem 2.</strong> (Canonical neighbourhood for Ricci flows, informal version)  Let <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2Cg%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2Cg%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2Cg%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="t \mapsto (M,g)" class="latex"> be a Ricci flow of compact 3-manifolds on a time interval <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%7D%5B0%2CT%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%7D%5B0%2CT%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%7D%5B0%2CT%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="{}[0,T)" class="latex">, without any embedded copy of <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CBbb%7BRP%7D%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\Bbb{RP}^2" class="latex"> with trivial normal bundle.  Then every point <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t%2Cx%29+%5Cin+%5B0%2CT%29+%5Ctimes+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t%2Cx%29+%5Cin+%5B0%2CT%29+%5Ctimes+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t%2Cx%29+%5Cin+%5B0%2CT%29+%5Ctimes+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="(t,x) \in [0,T) \times M" class="latex"> with sufficiently large scalar curvature is contained in a canonical neighbourhood.</p></blockquote>
<p>(Actually, as with many other components of this proof, we actually need a generalisation of this result for Ricci flow with surgery, but we will address this (non-trivial) complication later.)</p>
<p>The importance of this theorem lies in the fact that all the singular regions that need surgery will have large scalar curvature, and Theorem 2 provides the crucial topological and geometric control in order to perform surgery on these regions.  (This is a significant oversimplification, as one has to also study certain “horns” that appear at the singular time in order to find a particularly good place to perform surgery, but we will postpone discussion of this major additional issue later in this course.)</p>
<p>Theorem 2 is deduced from Corollary 1 and a significant number of additional arguments.  The strategy is to use a compactness-and-contradiction argument.  As a very crude first approximation, the proof goes as follows:</p>
<ol>
<li>Suppose for contradiction that Theorem 2 failed.  Then one could find a sequence <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29+%5Cin+%5B0%2CT%29+%5Ctimes+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29+%5Cin+%5B0%2CT%29+%5Ctimes+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29+%5Cin+%5B0%2CT%29+%5Ctimes+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="(t_n,x_n) \in [0,T) \times M" class="latex"> of points with <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=R%28t_n%2Cx_n%29+%5Cto+%2B%5Cinfty&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=R%28t_n%2Cx_n%29+%5Cto+%2B%5Cinfty&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=R%28t_n%2Cx_n%29+%5Cto+%2B%5Cinfty&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="R(t_n,x_n) \to +\infty" class="latex"> which were not contained in canonical neighbourhoods.</li>
<li>M, being compact, has finitely many components; by restricting attention to a subsequence of points if necessary, we can take M to be connected.</li>
<li>On any compact time interval <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%7D%5B0%2Ct%5D+%5Ctimes+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%7D%5B0%2Ct%5D+%5Ctimes+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7B%7D%5B0%2Ct%5D+%5Ctimes+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="{}[0,t] \times M" class="latex">, the scalar curvature is necessarily bounded, and thus <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t_n+%5Cto+T&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t_n+%5Cto+T&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t_n+%5Cto+T&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="t_n \to T" class="latex">.  As a consequence, if we define the rescaled Ricci flows <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g%5E%7B%28n%29%7D%28t%29+%3D+%5Cfrac%7B1%7D%7BL_n%5E2%7D+g%28+t_n+%2B+L_n%5E2+t+%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g%5E%7B%28n%29%7D%28t%29+%3D+%5Cfrac%7B1%7D%7BL_n%5E2%7D+g%28+t_n+%2B+L_n%5E2+t+%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g%5E%7B%28n%29%7D%28t%29+%3D+%5Cfrac%7B1%7D%7BL_n%5E2%7D+g%28+t_n+%2B+L_n%5E2+t+%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="g^{(n)}(t) = \frac{1}{L_n^2} g( t_n + L_n^2 t )" class="latex">, where <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=L_n+%3A%3D+R%28t_n%2Cx_n%29%5E%7B-1%2F2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=L_n+%3A%3D+R%28t_n%2Cx_n%29%5E%7B-1%2F2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=L_n+%3A%3D+R%28t_n%2Cx_n%29%5E%7B-1%2F2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="L_n := R(t_n,x_n)^{-1/2}" class="latex"> is the natural length scale associated to the scalar curvature at <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="(t_n,x_n)" class="latex">, then these flows will become increasingly ancient.   Note that in the limit (which we will not define rigorously yet, but think of a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gromov-Hausdorff_limit#Pointed_Gromov.E2.80.93Hausdorff_convergence">pointed Gromov-Hausdorff limit</a> for now), the increasingly large manifolds <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%2Cg%5E%7B%28n%29%7D%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%2Cg%5E%7B%28n%29%7D%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%2Cg%5E%7B%28n%29%7D%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="(M,g^{(n)}(t))" class="latex"> may cease to be compact, but will remain complete.</li>
<li>Because of the Hamilton-Ivey pinching phenomenon (Theorem 1 from <a class="snap_noshots" href="https://terrytao.wordpress.com/2008/04/04/285g-lecture-3-the-maximum-principle-and-the-pinching-phenomenon/">Lecture 3</a>), we expect the rescaled flows <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2C+g%5E%7B%28n%29%7D%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2C+g%5E%7B%28n%29%7D%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2C+g%5E%7B%28n%29%7D%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="t \mapsto (M, g^{(n)}(t))" class="latex"> to have non-negative Ricci curvature in the limit (and hence non-negative Riemann curvature also, as we are in three dimensions).</li>
<li>If we can pick the points <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="(t_n,x_n)" class="latex"> suitably (so that the scalar curvature <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=R%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=R%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=R%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="R(t_n,x_n)" class="latex"> is larger than or comparable to the scalar curvatures at other nearby points), then we should be able to ensure that the rescaled flows <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2C+g%5E%7B%28n%29%7D%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2C+g%5E%7B%28n%29%7D%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2C+g%5E%7B%28n%29%7D%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="t \mapsto (M, g^{(n)}(t))" class="latex"> have bounded curvature in the limit.</li>
<li>Since <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-noncollapsing is invariant under rescaling, the non-collapsing theorem (Theorem 2 of <a class="snap_noshots" href="https://terrytao.wordpress.com/2008/04/20/285g-lecture-7-rescaling-of-ricci-flows-and-kappa-noncollapsing/">Lecture 7</a>) should ensure that the rescaled flows remain <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-noncollapsed in the limit.</li>
<li>Since the rescaled scalar curvature at the base point <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_n&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_n&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_n&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="x_n" class="latex"> of <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%2Cg%5E%7B%28n%29%7D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%2Cg%5E%7B%28n%29%7D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%2Cg%5E%7B%28n%29%7D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="(M,g^{(n)})" class="latex"> is equal to 1 by construction, any limiting flow will be non-flat.</li>
<li>Various compactness theorems (of Gromov, Hamilton, and Perelman) exploiting the non-collapsed, bounded curvature, and parabolic nature of the rescaled Ricci flows now allows one to extract a limiting flow <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%2C+g%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%2C+g%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%2C+g%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="(M^{(\infty)}, g^{(\infty)})" class="latex">. This limit is initially in a fairly weak sense, but one can use parabolic theory to upgrade the convergence to quite a strong (and smooth) convergence.  In particular, the limit of the Ricci flows will remain a Ricci flow.</li>
<li>Applying 2-8, we see that the limiting flow <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%2C+g%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%2C+g%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%2C+g%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="(M^{(\infty)}, g^{(\infty)})" class="latex"> is a <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solution.</li>
<li>Applying Corollary 1, we conclude that every point in the limiting flow lies inside a canonical neighbourhood.  Using the strong nature of the convergence (and the scale-invariant nature of canonical neighbourhoods), we deduce that the points <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="(t_n,x_n)" class="latex"> also lie in canonical neighbourhoods for sufficiently large n, a contradiction.</li>
</ol>
<p>There are some non-trivial technical difficulties in executing the above scheme, especially in Step 5 and Step 8.  Step 8 will require some compactness theorems for <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions which we will deduce in later lectures.  For Step 5, the problem is that the points <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="(t_n,x_n)" class="latex"> that we are trying to place inside canonical neighbourhoods have large curvature, but they may be adjacent to other points of significantly higher curvature, so that the limiting flow <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%2C+g%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%2C+g%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%2C+g%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="(M^{(\infty)}, g^{(\infty)})" class="latex"> ends up having unbounded curvature.  To get around this, Perelman established Theorem 2 by a downwards induction argument on the curvature, first establishing the result for extremely high curvature, then for slightly less extreme curvature, and so forth.  The point is that with such an induction hypothesis, any potentially bad adjacent points of really high curvature will be safely tucked away in a canonical neighbourhood of high curvature, which in turn is connected to another canonical neighbourhood of high curvature, and so forth; some basic topological and geometric analysis then eventually lets us conclude that this bad point must in fact be quite far from the base point <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_n%2Cx_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="(t_n,x_n)" class="latex"> (much further away than the natural length scale <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=L_n&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=L_n&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=L_n&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="L_n" class="latex">, in particular), so that it does not show up in the limiting flow <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%2C+g%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%2C+g%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28M%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%2C+g%5E%7B%28%5Cinfty%29%7D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="(M^{(\infty)}, g^{(\infty)})" class="latex">.  We will discuss these issues in more detail in later lectures.</p>
<p style="text-align:center;">— Benchmarks in controlling <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions —</p>
<p>As mentioned earlier, the next few lectures will be focused on controlling <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions.  It turns out that the various properties in Definition 1 interact very well with each other, and give remarkably precise control on these solutions.  In this section we state (without proofs) some of the results we will establish concerning such solutions.</p>
<blockquote><p><strong>Proposition 1.</strong> (Consequences of Hamilton’s Harnack inequality)  Let <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2Cg%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2Cg%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2Cg%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="t \mapsto (M,g(t))" class="latex"> be a <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solution.  Then <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=R%28t%2Cx%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=R%28t%2Cx%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=R%28t%2Cx%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="R(t,x)" class="latex"> is a non-decreasing function of time.  Furthermore, for any <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_0%2Cx_0%29+%5Cin+%28-%5Cinfty%2C0%5D+%5Ctimes+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_0%2Cx_0%29+%5Cin+%28-%5Cinfty%2C0%5D+%5Ctimes+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28t_0%2Cx_0%29+%5Cin+%28-%5Cinfty%2C0%5D+%5Ctimes+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="(t_0,x_0) \in (-\infty,0] \times M" class="latex">, we have the pointwise inequalities</p>
<p style="text-align:center;"><img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdisplaystyle+%7C%5Cnabla+l_%7B%28t_0%2Cx_0%29%7D%7C%5E2+%2B+R+%5Cleq+%5Cfrac%7B3+l_%7B%28t_0%2Cx_0%29%7D%7D%7B%5Ctau%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdisplaystyle+%7C%5Cnabla+l_%7B%28t_0%2Cx_0%29%7D%7C%5E2+%2B+R+%5Cleq+%5Cfrac%7B3+l_%7B%28t_0%2Cx_0%29%7D%7D%7B%5Ctau%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdisplaystyle+%7C%5Cnabla+l_%7B%28t_0%2Cx_0%29%7D%7C%5E2+%2B+R+%5Cleq+%5Cfrac%7B3+l_%7B%28t_0%2Cx_0%29%7D%7D%7B%5Ctau%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\displaystyle |\nabla l_{(t_0,x_0)}|^2 + R \leq \frac{3 l_{(t_0,x_0)}}{\tau}" class="latex"> (1)</p>
<p>and</p>
<p style="text-align:center;"><img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdisplaystyle+-2+%5Cfrac%7Bl_%7B%28t_0%2Cx_0%29%7D%7D%7B%5Ctau%7D+%5Cleq+%5Cfrac%7B%5Cpartial+l_%7B%28t_0%2Cx_0%29%7D%7D%7B%5Cpartial+%5Ctau%7D+%5Cleq+%5Cfrac%7Bl_%7B%28t_0%2Cx_0%29%7D%7D%7B%5Ctau%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdisplaystyle+-2+%5Cfrac%7Bl_%7B%28t_0%2Cx_0%29%7D%7D%7B%5Ctau%7D+%5Cleq+%5Cfrac%7B%5Cpartial+l_%7B%28t_0%2Cx_0%29%7D%7D%7B%5Cpartial+%5Ctau%7D+%5Cleq+%5Cfrac%7Bl_%7B%28t_0%2Cx_0%29%7D%7D%7B%5Ctau%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdisplaystyle+-2+%5Cfrac%7Bl_%7B%28t_0%2Cx_0%29%7D%7D%7B%5Ctau%7D+%5Cleq+%5Cfrac%7B%5Cpartial+l_%7B%28t_0%2Cx_0%29%7D%7D%7B%5Cpartial+%5Ctau%7D+%5Cleq+%5Cfrac%7Bl_%7B%28t_0%2Cx_0%29%7D%7D%7B%5Ctau%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\displaystyle -2 \frac{l_{(t_0,x_0)}}{\tau} \leq \frac{\partial l_{(t_0,x_0)}}{\partial \tau} \leq \frac{l_{(t_0,x_0)}}{\tau}" class="latex"> (2)</p>
<p>on <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28-%5Cinfty%2Ct_0%29+%5Ctimes+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28-%5Cinfty%2Ct_0%29+%5Ctimes+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28-%5Cinfty%2Ct_0%29+%5Ctimes+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="(-\infty,t_0) \times M" class="latex">, where of course <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau+%3A%3D+t_0+-+t&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau+%3A%3D+t_0+-+t&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau+%3A%3D+t_0+-+t&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\tau := t_0 - t" class="latex"> is the backwards time variable.</p></blockquote>
<p>These inequalities follow from an important <a class="snap_noshots" href="http://www.ams.org/mathscinet-getitem?mr=1198607">Harnack inequality of Hamilton</a> (also related to earlier <a class="snap_noshots" href="http://www.ams.org/mathscinet-getitem?mr=834612">work of Li and Yau</a>) that we will discuss in the next lecture.  These results rely primarily on the ancient and non-negatively curved nature of <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions, as well as the Ricci flow equation <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdot+g+%3D+-2+%5Chbox%7BRic%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdot+g+%3D+-2+%5Chbox%7BRic%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdot+g+%3D+-2+%5Chbox%7BRic%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\dot g = -2 \hbox{Ric}" class="latex"> of course.</p>
<p>Now one can handle the two-dimensional case:</p>
<blockquote><p><strong>Proposition 2. </strong>(Classification of 2-dimensional <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions) The only two-dimensional <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions are the round shrinking 2-spheres.</p></blockquote>
<p>This proposition relies on first studying a certain asymptotic limit of the <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solution, known as the asymptotic soliton, to be defined later.   One shows that this asymptotic limit is a round shrinking 2-sphere, which implies that the original <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solution is asymptotically a round shrinking 2-sphere.  One can then invoke Hamilton’s rounding theorem to finish the claim.</p>
<p>Turning now to three dimensions, the first important result that the curvature R decays slower at infinity than what scaling naively predicts.</p>
<blockquote><p><strong>Proposition 3.</strong> (Asymptotic curvature) Let <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2Cg%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2Cg%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2Cg%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="t \mapsto (M,g(t))" class="latex"> be a 3-dimensional <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex"> solution which is not compact.  Then for any time <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cin+%28-%5Cinfty%2C0%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cin+%28-%5Cinfty%2C0%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cin+%28-%5Cinfty%2C0%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="t \in (-\infty,0)" class="latex"> and any base point <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p+%5Cin+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p+%5Cin+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p+%5Cin+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="p \in M" class="latex">, we have <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Climsup_%7Bx+%5Cto+%5Cinfty%7D+R%28t%2Cx%29+d_%7Bg%28t%29%7D%28x%2Cp%29%5E2+%3D+%2B%5Cinfty&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Climsup_%7Bx+%5Cto+%5Cinfty%7D+R%28t%2Cx%29+d_%7Bg%28t%29%7D%28x%2Cp%29%5E2+%3D+%2B%5Cinfty&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Climsup_%7Bx+%5Cto+%5Cinfty%7D+R%28t%2Cx%29+d_%7Bg%28t%29%7D%28x%2Cp%29%5E2+%3D+%2B%5Cinfty&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\limsup_{x \to \infty} R(t,x) d_{g(t)}(x,p)^2 = +\infty" class="latex">.</p></blockquote>
<p>The proof of Proposition 3 is based on another compactness-and-contradiction argument which also heavily exploits some splitting theorems in Riemannian geometry, as well as the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soul_theorem">soul theorem</a>.</p>
<p>The increasing curvature at infinity can be used to show that the volume does not grow as fast at infinity as scaling predicts:</p>
<blockquote>
<p style="text-align:left;"><strong>Proposition 4.</strong> (Asymptotic volume collapse) Let <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2Cg%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2Cg%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cmapsto+%28M%2Cg%28t%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="t \mapsto (M,g(t))" class="latex"> be a 3-dimensional <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex"> solution which is not compact.  Then for any time <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cin+%28-%5Cinfty%2C0%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cin+%28-%5Cinfty%2C0%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t+%5Cin+%28-%5Cinfty%2C0%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="t \in (-\infty,0)" class="latex"> and any base point <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p+%5Cin+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p+%5Cin+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p+%5Cin+M&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="p \in M" class="latex">, we have <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Climsup_%7Br+%5Cto+%2B%5Cinfty%7D+%5Chbox%7BVol%7D_%7Bg%28t%29%7D%28+B_%7Bg%28t%29%7D%29%28p%2Cr%29+%29+%2F+r%5E3+%3D+0&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Climsup_%7Br+%5Cto+%2B%5Cinfty%7D+%5Chbox%7BVol%7D_%7Bg%28t%29%7D%28+B_%7Bg%28t%29%7D%29%28p%2Cr%29+%29+%2F+r%5E3+%3D+0&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Climsup_%7Br+%5Cto+%2B%5Cinfty%7D+%5Chbox%7BVol%7D_%7Bg%28t%29%7D%28+B_%7Bg%28t%29%7D%29%28p%2Cr%29+%29+%2F+r%5E3+%3D+0&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\limsup_{r \to +\infty} \hbox{Vol}_{g(t)}( B_{g(t)})(p,r) ) / r^3 = 0" class="latex">.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Note that Proposition 4 does not contradict the non-collapsed nature of the flow, since one does not expect bounded normalised curvature at extremely large scales.  Proposition 4 morally follows from Bishop-Gromov comparison geometry theory, but its proof in fact uses yet another compactness-and-contradiction argument combined with splitting theory.</p>
<p>An important variant of Proposition 4 and Proposition 3 (and yet another compactness-and-contradiction argument) states that on any ball <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B_%7Bg%280%29%7D%28p%2Cr%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B_%7Bg%280%29%7D%28p%2Cr%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B_%7Bg%280%29%7D%28p%2Cr%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="B_{g(0)}(p,r)" class="latex"> at time zero on which the volume is large (e.g. larger than <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cnu+r%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cnu+r%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cnu+r%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\nu r^3" class="latex"> for some <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cnu+%3E+0&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cnu+%3E+0&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cnu+%3E+0&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\nu > 0" class="latex">), one has bounded normalised curvature, thus <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=R+%3D+O_%5Cnu%28+1+%2F+r%5E2+%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=R+%3D+O_%5Cnu%28+1+%2F+r%5E2+%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=R+%3D+O_%5Cnu%28+1+%2F+r%5E2+%29&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="R = O_\nu( 1 / r^2 )" class="latex"> on this ball.  This fact helps us deduce</p>
<blockquote><p><strong>Theorem 3.</strong> (Perelman compactness theorem, informal version)  The space of all pointed <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions (allowing <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa+%3E+0&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa+%3E+0&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa+%3E+0&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa > 0" class="latex"> to range over the positive real numbers) is compact (in a suitable topology) after normalising the scalar curvature at the base point to be 1.</p></blockquote>
<p>One corollary of this compactness is that there is in fact a universal <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa_0+%3E+0&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa_0+%3E+0&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa_0+%3E+0&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa_0 > 0" class="latex"> such that every <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solution is a <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa_0&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa_0&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa_0&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa_0" class="latex">-solution.  (Indeed, the proof of this universality is one of the key steps in the proof of the above theorem.)  This theorem is proven by establishing some uniform curvature bounds on <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions which come from the previous volume analysis.</p>
<p>The proof of Theorem 1 (and thus Corollary 1) follows from this compactness once one can classify the asymptotic solitons mentioned earlier.  This task in turn requires many of the techniques already mentioned, together with some variational analysis of the gradient curves of the potential function f that controls the geometry of the soliton.</p>

		<div class="comment-content">
			<img referrerpolicy="no-referrer" alt="Unknown's avatar" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/blavatar/bd4bda4207561b6998f10dec44b570f04ff4072b20f89162d525b186dfca3e49?s=32" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/blavatar/bd4bda4207561b6998f10dec44b570f04ff4072b20f89162d525b186dfca3e49?s=32 1x, https://secure.gravatar.com/blavatar/bd4bda4207561b6998f10dec44b570f04ff4072b20f89162d525b186dfca3e49?s=48 1.5x, https://secure.gravatar.com/blavatar/bd4bda4207561b6998f10dec44b570f04ff4072b20f89162d525b186dfca3e49?s=64 2x, https://secure.gravatar.com/blavatar/bd4bda4207561b6998f10dec44b570f04ff4072b20f89162d525b186dfca3e49?s=96 3x, https://secure.gravatar.com/blavatar/bd4bda4207561b6998f10dec44b570f04ff4072b20f89162d525b186dfca3e49?s=128 4x" class="avatar avatar-32" height="32" width="32" loading="lazy" decoding="async">			<p>[…] The classical proofs of the parabolic Harnack inequality do not give particularly sharp bounds on the constant . Such sharp bounds were obtained by Li and Yau, especially in the case of the scalar heat equation (1) in the case of static manifolds of non-negative Ricci curvature, using Bochner-type identities and the scalar maximum principle. In fact, a stronger differential version of (3) was obtained which implied (3) by an integration along spacetime curves (closely analogous to the -geodesics considered in earlier lectures). These bounds were particularly strong in the case of ancient solutions (in which one can send ). Subsequently, Hamilton applied his tensor-valued maximum principle together with some remarkably delicate tensor algebra manipulations to obtain Harnack inequalities of Li-Yau type for solutions to the Ricci flow (2) with bounded non-negative Riemannian curvature. In particular, this inequality applies to the -solutions introduced in the previous lecture. […]</p>
<div class="cs-rating pd-rating" id="pd_rating_holder_132742_comm_29890"></div>		</div>
