	<div class="comment even thread-even depth-1 vcard" id="comment-29898">
		<div class="comment-metadata">
			<p class="comment-permalink"><a href="https://terrytao.wordpress.com/2008/05/16/285g-lecture-12-high-curvature-regions-of-ricci-flow-and-%ce%ba-solutions/#comment-29898" title="Permalink to this comment">19 May, 2008 at 12:57 pm</a></p>
			<p class="comment-author"><strong class="fn">Sylvain Maillot</strong></p>
					</div>

		<div class="comment-content">
			<img referrerpolicy="no-referrer" alt="Sylvain Maillot's avatar" src="https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/ebecc7af3157cae07b2898e45f9eee73d7912daccd7d6e218957ea4408801015?s=32&d=identicon&r=PG" srcset="https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/ebecc7af3157cae07b2898e45f9eee73d7912daccd7d6e218957ea4408801015?s=32&d=identicon&r=PG 1x, https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/ebecc7af3157cae07b2898e45f9eee73d7912daccd7d6e218957ea4408801015?s=48&d=identicon&r=PG 1.5x, https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/ebecc7af3157cae07b2898e45f9eee73d7912daccd7d6e218957ea4408801015?s=64&d=identicon&r=PG 2x, https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/ebecc7af3157cae07b2898e45f9eee73d7912daccd7d6e218957ea4408801015?s=96&d=identicon&r=PG 3x, https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/ebecc7af3157cae07b2898e45f9eee73d7912daccd7d6e218957ea4408801015?s=128&d=identicon&r=PG 4x" class="avatar avatar-32" height="32" width="32" loading="lazy" decoding="async">			<p>Another minor correction: in Example 2, you should delete the words<br>
“shrinking round” before <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E1%5Ctimes+%5Cmathbb%7BR%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E1%5Ctimes+%5Cmathbb%7BR%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%5E1%5Ctimes+%5Cmathbb%7BR%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="S^1\times \mathbb{R}" class="latex"> : this manifold<br>
is flat, so it does not shrink by Ricci flow (and I wouldn’t call it “round”.)</p>
<p>A more serious point: I am surprised to see five cases in the classification of<br>
<img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions (Theorem 1), since in Perelman there are only four.<br>
What is exactly the difference between case 3 “C-component” and case 5<br>
“doubly <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="C" class="latex">-capped strong <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cvarepsilon&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\varepsilon" class="latex">-tube” ?</p>
<div class="cs-rating pd-rating" id="pd_rating_holder_132742_comm_29898"></div>		</div>
		<div class="reply">
				<a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="https://terrytao.wordpress.com/2008/05/16/285g-lecture-12-high-curvature-regions-of-ricci-flow-and-%ce%ba-solutions/?replytocom=29898#respond" data-commentid="29898" data-postid="384" data-belowelement="comment-29898" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Sylvain Maillot" aria-label="Reply to Sylvain Maillot">Reply</a>		</div>
	</div>
	
	<div class="comment byuser comment-author-teorth bypostauthor odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1 vcard" id="comment-29901">
		<div class="comment-metadata">
			<p class="comment-permalink"><a href="https://terrytao.wordpress.com/2008/05/16/285g-lecture-12-high-curvature-regions-of-ricci-flow-and-%ce%ba-solutions/#comment-29901" title="Permalink to this comment">19 May, 2008 at 2:39 pm</a></p>
			<p class="comment-author"><strong class="fn"><a href="http://www.math.ucla.edu/~tao" class="url" rel="ugc external nofollow">Terence Tao</a></strong></p>
					</div>

		<div class="comment-content">
			<img referrerpolicy="no-referrer" alt="Terence Tao's avatar" src="https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/d7f0e4a42bbbf58ffa656c92d4a32b2b6752e802dfa4cb919e5774dcfda006c0?s=32&d=identicon&r=PG" srcset="https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/d7f0e4a42bbbf58ffa656c92d4a32b2b6752e802dfa4cb919e5774dcfda006c0?s=32&d=identicon&r=PG 1x, https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/d7f0e4a42bbbf58ffa656c92d4a32b2b6752e802dfa4cb919e5774dcfda006c0?s=48&d=identicon&r=PG 1.5x, https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/d7f0e4a42bbbf58ffa656c92d4a32b2b6752e802dfa4cb919e5774dcfda006c0?s=64&d=identicon&r=PG 2x, https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/d7f0e4a42bbbf58ffa656c92d4a32b2b6752e802dfa4cb919e5774dcfda006c0?s=96&d=identicon&r=PG 3x, https://1.gravatar.com/avatar/d7f0e4a42bbbf58ffa656c92d4a32b2b6752e802dfa4cb919e5774dcfda006c0?s=128&d=identicon&r=PG 4x" class="avatar avatar-32" height="32" width="32" loading="lazy" decoding="async">			<p>Dear Sylvain: Thanks again for the corrections!</p>
<p>Regarding Theorem 1, I am basing this on Theorem 9.93 of Morgan-Tian (though I am grouping the cases a little differently).  As I understand it, a C-component and a doubly C-capped strong epsilon-tube are topologically the same, but geometrically rather different; in the former the sectional curvature is bounded above and below everywhere, whereas in the latter the sectional curvature can be very small in the epsilon-tube component of the manifold (in planes parallel to the direction of the tube, of course).  Also, if we normalise the maximal curvature to be 1, then C-components need to have diameter comparable to 1, but doubly C-capped epsilon-tubes can have arbitrarily large diameter.</p>
<p>Perhaps the key difference here between Morgan-Tian and Perelman is that in Morgan-Tian one tries to classify the global structure of kappa-solutions, even though for applications it is only the local structure (i.e. the canonical neighbourhoods) which is of importance.  Thus, for instance, if one takes a doubly C-capped strong epsilon-tube, the canonical neighbourhood of any given point in such an object would be either an epsilon-neck, epsilon-cap, or a closed manifold in Perelman’s notation, depending on whether the tube is long or short and whether the point lies in the middle of the manifold or near one of the ends.</p>
<p>[In Morgan-Tian, the relevant canonical neighbourhood theorem is Corollary 9.94; the definition of canonical neighbourhoods on page 232 (and reproduced here as Definition 2) has exactly four cases and matches up with the corresponding notion in Perelman’s second paper.]</p>
<div class="cs-rating pd-rating" id="pd_rating_holder_132742_comm_29901"></div>		</div>
		<div class="reply">
				<a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="https://terrytao.wordpress.com/2008/05/16/285g-lecture-12-high-curvature-regions-of-ricci-flow-and-%ce%ba-solutions/?replytocom=29901#respond" data-commentid="29901" data-postid="384" data-belowelement="comment-29901" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Terence Tao" aria-label="Reply to Terence Tao">Reply</a>		</div>
	</div>
	
	<div class="comment even thread-even depth-1 vcard" id="comment-29924">
		<div class="comment-metadata">
			<p class="comment-permalink"><a href="https://terrytao.wordpress.com/2008/05/16/285g-lecture-12-high-curvature-regions-of-ricci-flow-and-%ce%ba-solutions/#comment-29924" title="Permalink to this comment">20 May, 2008 at 10:12 am</a></p>
			<p class="comment-author"><strong class="fn">Sylvain Maillot</strong></p>
					</div>

		<div class="comment-content">
			<img referrerpolicy="no-referrer" alt="Sylvain Maillot's avatar" src="https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/ebecc7af3157cae07b2898e45f9eee73d7912daccd7d6e218957ea4408801015?s=32&d=identicon&r=PG" srcset="https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/ebecc7af3157cae07b2898e45f9eee73d7912daccd7d6e218957ea4408801015?s=32&d=identicon&r=PG 1x, https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/ebecc7af3157cae07b2898e45f9eee73d7912daccd7d6e218957ea4408801015?s=48&d=identicon&r=PG 1.5x, https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/ebecc7af3157cae07b2898e45f9eee73d7912daccd7d6e218957ea4408801015?s=64&d=identicon&r=PG 2x, https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/ebecc7af3157cae07b2898e45f9eee73d7912daccd7d6e218957ea4408801015?s=96&d=identicon&r=PG 3x, https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/ebecc7af3157cae07b2898e45f9eee73d7912daccd7d6e218957ea4408801015?s=128&d=identicon&r=PG 4x" class="avatar avatar-32" height="32" width="32" loading="lazy" decoding="async">			<p>OK. In fact, if you take a <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solution which is a <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="C" class="latex">-component at time zero and look into its past, then you will see a doubly capped neck, where the neck part becomes longer and longer as time goes to negative infinity.</p>
<p>This means that you can merge those two cases if you add time-shifting in your equivalence relation (in addition to isometry and rescaling). I would say that your statement is more a classification of time-zero slices of <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions than a classification of <img src="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002" srcset="https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002 1x, https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ckappa&bg=ffffff&fg=545454&s=0&c=20201002&zoom=4.5 4x" alt="\kappa" class="latex">-solutions strictly speaking.</p>
<p>Well, all this is irrelevant to the Poincare conjecture anyway…</p>
<div class="cs-rating pd-rating" id="pd_rating_holder_132742_comm_29924"></div>		</div>

					</div>

		<div class="comment-content">
			<img referrerpolicy="no-referrer" alt="Unknown's avatar" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/blavatar/bd4bda4207561b6998f10dec44b570f04ff4072b20f89162d525b186dfca3e49?s=32" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/blavatar/bd4bda4207561b6998f10dec44b570f04ff4072b20f89162d525b186dfca3e49?s=32 1x, https://secure.gravatar.com/blavatar/bd4bda4207561b6998f10dec44b570f04ff4072b20f89162d525b186dfca3e49?s=48 1.5x, https://secure.gravatar.com/blavatar/bd4bda4207561b6998f10dec44b570f04ff4072b20f89162d525b186dfca3e49?s=64 2x, https://secure.gravatar.com/blavatar/bd4bda4207561b6998f10dec44b570f04ff4072b20f89162d525b186dfca3e49?s=96 3x, https://secure.gravatar.com/blavatar/bd4bda4207561b6998f10dec44b570f04ff4072b20f89162d525b186dfca3e49?s=128 4x" class="avatar avatar-32" height="32" width="32" loading="lazy" decoding="async">			<p>[…] 2 June, 2008 in 285G – poincare conjecture, math.DG by Terence Tao Tags: compactness and contradiction, geometric limits, gradient shrinking solitons, kappa-solutions, necks   Having classified all asymptotic gradient shrinking solitons in three and fewer dimensions in the previous lecture, we now use this classification, combined with extensive use of compactness and contradiction arguments, as well as the comparison geometry of complete Riemannian manifolds of non-negative curvature, to understand the structure of -solutions in these dimensions, with the aim being to state and prove precise versions of Theorem 1 and Corollary 1 from Lecture 12. […]</p>
<div class="cs-rating pd-rating" id="pd_rating_holder_132742_comm_30184"></div>		</div>

		// Core loads scripts in this order. See: https://github.com/WordPress/WordPress/blob/a59eb9d39c4fcba834b70c9e8dfd64feeec10ba6/wp-includes/class-wp-scripts.php#L428.
		return loadExtra(handle, 'translations')
			.then(() => loadExtra(handle, 'before'))
			.then(() => loadExternalScript(handle))
			.then(() => loadExtra(handle, 'after'));
	}
} )();
</script>
</body></html>
